item.title: Hash Compression
item.description: It can be very useful to compress a hash value so that it becomes smaller, there are some methods to achieve this:

item.title: Dynamic Arrays
item.description: Normally, adding an element to an already full [[/notes/Array|Array]] would take $O(n)$ time, if you resize it by 1 cell everytime an element is added, that is.

item.title: Big Omega Notation
item.description: The big omega notation $\Omega(n)$ is basically the opposite of [[/notes/Big-Oh Notation|Big-Oh Notation]], what it does is that it shows the time an algorithm in the best-case relative to its input size, n.

item.title: Big-Oh Notation
item.description: Big-Oh notation is a way of calculating the maximum time an algorithm can take relative to its input size. The two ways to calculate big-oh notation is:

item.title: Big-Theta Notation
item.description: Big theta notation is a little more complicated, the Big-Theta notation covers both the worst and best-case scenarios that an algorithm might have relative to its input (n).
